Text:
This generation is not okay.

We are the most connected generation in history - yet we feel lonelier than ever.

We have:

Friends in every corner of the world but no one to call when we break down at 2 AM.

Thousands of likes on selfies but no one who genuinely likes us for who we are.

A ‘perfect’ life online but an empty, exhausted soul in reality.

Look around:

People are dating just to avoid being alone. Love is no longer about connection - it’s about convenience.

Looks matter more than loyalty. A six-pack gets more respect than a kind heart.

Luxury is being bought on EMI. We’d rather impress strangers than build real financial stability.

Success is about looking successful. People rent expensive cars for Instagram but can’t afford their rent.

Friendships are based on utility. "What can you do for me?" matters more than genuine care.

Breakups are text messages. Ghosting is normal. Cheating is just a "mistake."

Marriage is seen as a burden. People want weddings, not lifelong commitments.

Jobs drain us. We work long hours, burn out, and call it "hustle."

Cheating is normal. People call it a "mistake" while someone’s life falls apart.

Fake people win. The ones who manipulate, step over others, and lie get ahead.

Mental health is a trend. Everyone posts about it, but no one listens when someone truly struggles.

Success is about flexing, not achieving. Rent a luxury car, post a reel, fool the world.

Kindness is a performance. Show empathy online, be rude in real life.

Relationships are temporary. Love today, cheat tomorrow, move on the next day.

Loyalty is outdated. Who needs commitment when you have options?

If you're kind, pure, and loyal, this world will use you, break you, and leave you behind.

If you're too nice, people will take advantage of you.

If you're too honest, people will call you naïve.

If you're too loyal, people will treat you like an option.

If you're too genuine, people will think you're weak.

We chase things we don’t even want - just because the world tells us to.

We seek validation from people who wouldn’t even show up to our funeral.

We’re so scared of being left out that we forget what actually matters.

Maybe the problem isn’t society. Maybe it’s us.
Maybe we need to stop chasing, stop flexing, stop pretending.

Maybe the real flex is peace.

Maybe real success is having people who love you.

Maybe true happiness is living for yourself, not for likes.

If you're constantly seeing motivational posts like "I wake up at 4 AM, meditate for an hour, run a marathon, and close five deals before breakfast," I just want to remind you… it’s okay to sleep in till 10 AM and stare at the ceiling questioning life.

We all sometimes feel like we’re falling behind - people are getting dream jobs, buying houses, launching startups, and here we are… *celebrating the fact that we finally did our laundry.*

But you know what? *That’s okay.*

Life is not a productivity contest. Some people sprint, some people jog, and some (like me) take snack breaks every five minutes. The goal is to *not burn out before reaching the finish line.*

So if you need a break, take it. If you want to rest, do it guilt-free. *Your worth is not measured by how many ‘grindset’ reels you watch.*

And remember, even your phone needs to recharge. So why shouldn’t you?

Cracked 5+ interviews last month - here’s exactly how I did it.

Job hunting isn’t easy. It’s frustrating, unpredictable, and often feels unfair. But having a structured approach helped me stay sane and maximize my chances.

Here’s what worked:

1. Resume = First Impression Matters-

Tailored my resume for different roles (not rewriting, just tweaking keywords).

Made sure the first two lines of each job experience showed impact, not just tasks.

2. Applied Smart, Not Just Fast-

Prioritized companies that matched my skill set instead of mass applying.

Used LinkedIn, Wellfound, and Naukri for targeted searches.

Cold messaged hiring managers when possible (not just “Hi,” but value-driven messages).

3. Interviewing: Storytelling & Clarity Over Buzzwords-

For behavioral rounds: Used STAR format (Situation, Task, Action, Result) but kept it conversational.

For technical rounds: Thought out loud, asked clarifying questions, and didn’t rush to the answer.

P.S - I even solved a differential/integration question in one of the interviews, so be ready for everything :)

4. Post-Interview: The Follow-Up That Works-

Sent thoughtful follow-up emails that reiterated my strengths & interest.

If rejected, always ask for feedback and refine your approach.

Hope this helps :)

Why should a corporate majdoor go to the gym?

Channelise your anger, lift heavy and next time when a jerk comes and taunts you for your work, you'll feel the power - I deadlifted 145 today, I can deadlift 2 of him.

You'll not have to worry about your mental health anymore. Start running and you'll be confused - which is worse? my mental health or my physical health?

You'll stop overthinking. Because instead of lying awake at night questioning your life choices, you'll be passed out by 10 PM thinking — Was that my last set or did I black out?

And forget office politics — once you hit leg day properly, the only thing you'll be thinking is, "How do I climb these 3 stairs without crying?"

The next time someone dumps extra work on you at 6 PM, you won't get angry - you'll smile and think, "I'll use this frustration to hit a new PR tomorrow."

Cardio will teach you life’s biggest lesson - no matter how fast you run, you can’t escape your problems… or your boss's 7 AM meeting invite.

Unpopular opinion:

AI is making people dumber and lonelier.

For the simplest tasks, people have started using AI. 
Even some are using it to share personal conversations (instead of talking to a friend).

AI was meant to make life easier, not replace human connection.

- Struggling with writing an email? People now ask AI.
- Can't decide what to wear? People ask AI.
- Feeling sad or lonely? Some vent to AI instead of calling a friend.

While AI can be helpful, relying on it for every decision is dangerous. We're outsourcing our thinking, creativity, and even emotions to algorithms.

The result? People are becoming less independent, less connected, and more isolated.

AI is a tool - use it wisely. Because no chatbot can replace the warmth of a real conversation or the comfort of someone who genuinely cares.

What are your thoughts? Is AI making us smarter or just more dependent?

Imagine spending weeks perfecting your resume. Hours crafting the perfect cover letter. Days preparing for an interview that never comes — because the job itself was never real.

This is ghost hiring.

What is Ghost Hiring?

Ghost hiring is when companies post job openings that they have no intention of filling. Sometimes it's to:

1. Collect Resumes — Building a talent pool for future needs.

2. Show Growth — To appear as if the company is expanding.

3. Keep Employees on Edge — Making internal teams believe they can be replaced.

4. Satisfy Policies — Companies might post jobs just to meet the internal hiring process requirements, even if they’ve already chosen a candidate.

But what does this mean for job seekers? It’s heartbreaking.

You refresh your inbox every day, hoping for an update. You convince yourself you didn’t get a reply because maybe they’re busy - or maybe you need to improve your skills.

In reality, you never stood a chance because the role wasn’t real in the first place.

The Emotional Impact:
Ghost hiring doesn’t just waste time - it crushes self-esteem. Candidates start questioning their worth. They feel like they aren’t ‘good enough,’ when in reality, they were never even considered.

It leads to:
- Imposter Syndrome — “Maybe I’m just not skilled enough.”

- Burnout — Applying to hundreds of roles without meaningful responses.

- Anxiety & Depression — Feeling powerless in your career.

To those facing this:

It’s *not your fault*. The silence you’re experiencing isn’t a reflection of your skills or talent. Sometimes, the system itself is broken.

What can job seekers do?

1. Ask Directly: During interviews, ask, “Is this role budget-approved and actively being hired for?” Genuine recruiters will answer honestly.

2. Watch for Red Flags: If a role is repeatedly reposted but no one you know has been hired, that’s a warning sign.

3. Focus on Networking: Referrals often bypass the “ghost” stage because you’re connected to someone inside.

And to companies practicing ghost hiring:
Please understand - these are real people. Behind every resume is a person battling self-doubt, holding on to hope, and trying to build a future.

If you're posting jobs you don’t plan to fill, remember this: Your ‘strategy’ is someone else’s heartbreak.

To everyone who is still applying despite the silence - you are strong, resilient, and capable.

One day, the right opportunity will come - and when it does, it will be *real*.

Dear HRs,
If candidates had the power to rate YOU after interviews, imagine how wild those reviews would be:

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ ‘Great communication. Gave clear timelines. Highly recommend.’

⭐️⭐️ ‘Ghosted me after 4 rounds. Still waiting for closure.’

⭐️ ‘Said the salary was ‘competitive.’ Turns out, they meant competitively low.’

⭐️ ‘Chaache ke bhatije ko hire kar liye 5 rounds lene ke baad mere.’

It’s about time candidates get a ‘Rate My Recruiter’ platform. I'd love to see who survives that leaderboard. 😎

Degrees vs. Certifications vs. Experience: Which One Actually Matters?

A degree used to be the golden ticket. Now? Not so much.

Here’s the reality:

Degree: Helps you get past HR filters.

Certifications: Shows you’re learning, but doesn’t guarantee skills.

Experience: Actually proves you can do the job.

If companies really want "skills over degrees," why do job descriptions still say 'IIT/NIT preferred'?

If you are an anime fan, you know what the "evil arc" means.

I am a big fan of that word "evil arc"

Your Evil Arc is Just the Beginning.

Sometimes, life pushes you into a corner. 
You get betrayed. Overlooked. Underestimated. 

People take you for granted. They mock your dreams. 
You help them, but when you need support - silence. 

And then, something inside you changes. 

You stop explaining. Stop seeking validation. 

The old version of you? Gone. 

Now, you work in silence. You build in the dark. 
You become sharper. Stronger. Ruthless with your time and energy. 

This is your *evil arc* - but not in the way they think. 

You're not becoming heartless. 

You're just done playing small. 

And when you rise, they’ll call it luck. 
But you’ll know - this was the moment you chose yourself. 

Let them doubt. Let them gossip. 
You have an empire to build.

To the woman reading this:

You don’t need to be perfect.
You don’t have to "do it all."
You are enough - just as you are.

You are more than your productivity. More than your achievements. More than the expectations placed upon you.

Not every woman is "breaking barriers."

Some are just trying to survive.

The woman hiding her tears at work because "strong women don’t cry."

The mother battling guilt, whether she chooses career or family.

The woman exhausted from proving she’s enough - at home, at work, everywhere.

This Women’s Day, let’s celebrate all women. Not just the CEOs, the record-breakers, the fighters -

But also the quiet warriors. The ones battling self-doubt. The ones carrying invisible burdens.

Because womanhood isn’t about being "unstoppable" -

It’s about being human.

This Women’s Day, I hope you find peace. I hope you find love.

And that should be enough.
But most of all - I hope you find yourself.

Because you deserve it.

Gen Z doesnt want to work? Or do companies just not want to pay?

Boomers: “Back in my day, we worked 14 hours for ₹2,000 a month!”

Gen Z: “Okay, that’s tragic. Not a flex.”

Somewhere along the way, we confused hustle with exploitation.

Here’s a wild idea:

Maybe freshers deserve to be paid.

Maybe passion doesn’t mean working weekends for free.

Maybe “work-life balance” shouldn’t be something you earn after burning out.

If you want experience, offer mentorship. If you want free work, hire interns - and PAY them.

Because Gen Z isn’t “lazy.” They just know that exposure doesn’t pay rent.
